FacilityName: Hanover Municipal Water Works - Filter Plant

_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Chlorinator designed according to Chlorine Institue standards
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: The Borough performs preventative maintenance and tests alarms monthly.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Borough of Hanover Municipal Authority owns a potable water treatment and distribution system for the Borough of Hanover and some surrounding communities, located in York and Adams Counties, Pennsylvania.  This system is operated by the Borough of Hanover.  The Hanover Municipal Water Works Filter Plant, located at 235 Old Hanover Road, processes up to 11 million gallons per day of water drawn from the South Branch Conewego Creek to yield potable water.  Treatment processes at the Plant include pretreatment, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, fluoridation, and chlorine disinfection.  Chemical addition is utilized to control taste, odor, and corrosion.  The Plant is typically operated 24 hours per day, Monday through Saturday, with 8-hour coverage on Sundays and major holidays.

The Water Works Filter Plant includes a Chlorination Room, which contains four (4) one ton cylinders of chlorine liquefied under pressure, chlorinators, various safety equipment, and instrumentation consisting of flow recorders, electrical panels, and a gas detector/alarm unit.  The chlorinator system uses remote vacuum actuated feed lines and has high pressure regulators attached directly to the chlorine vessel gas valves to mitigate high pressure gas releases through the chlorinator system.  Water treatment operators regularly check the room and its equipment, inventory the rate of chlorine use, and adjust the rate as necessary.  The maximum intended inventory of chlorine gas for planning purposes is 8,000 pounds.

Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed using the RMP*Comp program distributed by the Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention Office of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA).  This model determines the distance traveled by chlorine released until its concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint of 0.0087 milligrams per Liter (mg/L).  The chlorine toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/L in air represents the American Industrial

Under a mutual aid agreement between Adams County and York County, the York County HAZMAT team will provide additional support for a chlorine leak.  The York County HAZMAT team is state certified and undergoes extensive training in dealing with a variety of hazardous material incidents, including chlorine gas leaks.  


Recommendations to improve safety were made following a June 25, 2013 inspection of the disinfection system by the Borough's Consulting Engineer.  These recommendations include improvements to written emergency standard operating procedures (SOPs) and development of an operator training program that provides annual refresher training on proper safety and handling of chlorine, as well as chlorine leak response procedures.
